  {panel}

Right now, our searches are complicated by the fact that each field on the object goes into a different term in the index.

The advantages of doing this are that we can weight titles higher, for example.

The disadvantage is that if someone searches for "foo AND bar", you'll only get a match if foo and bar are in the same field: an email addressed to Charles, with beer in the message body won't match "charles AND beer"

I've fixed this for the simplest case - title of a CEO for CONF-3426, but we need a more general solution where everything we want to be searched on gets put in a single field.
fields.summary: Make one big searchableText term in Lucene containing all searchable text for that entity

{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of November 2, 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
(i) Hi Everyone,

Collaborative editing is available for all Cloud customers via opt-in. For information on how to activate collaborative editing: [https://confluence.atlassian.com/confcloud/collaborative-editing-828790374.html]

For Server customers, *collaborative editing is now released in Confleunce 6.0!* Head to the [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Confluence+6.0+Release+Notes] for the full low down on Confluence 6.0.

Thanks for your feedback and support.

Confluence Product Management
{panel}
—

When User A is editing a page and User B attempts to edit the same page, User B should receive a waiting screen notification while User A receives a real-time prompt to either begin a collaborative editing session, or reject User B's edit request and allow them to view updates in 'watch' mode instead.

If User A selects a collaborative editing session, both User A and User B will switch to a shared screen mode where all text changes are shared. Any text that is entered or changed will be reflected on all user's screens, with the user who made the most recent change having priority. During collaborative editing, a small page chat window is added to the screen across all participants so that they can chat about updates. This chat log is linked to the page version on save and accessible from the page history in the same way as update comments are shown. It should also be indexed.

Any users who are in a collaborative editing session may switch to 'watch' mode at any time, where they no longer have the ability to make page updates but can still see the edits made in real time. Both watchers and editors can always communicate with each other via page chat. This allows users who were rejected from making edits to communicate with the current page editor.

If a minimum connection speed is required to collaboratively edit, the session should check this for any client attempting to join a collaborative session and automatically deny the session if the test is failed. As more users request to join a concurrent editing session, join requests should start showing a soft limit warning when performance goes below a certain threshold, followed by hard limit automatic rejection at the point at which editing performance would be seriously affected.

This request may be useful in combination with sectional editing, where a user can select to edit only one section of a document, so the implementation should take into account that sectional editing may be implemented in future.

This request may be useful in combination with notes to indicate when any users are editing a page. This note could be an AJAX notification that appears within a minute of it being edited for all users viewing that page.
fields.summary: Real-time concurrent editing to allow multiple editors to collaboratively edit content
Ability to enforce password requirements

We are starting to archive more email into Confluence, and suddenly hit upon an unfortunate limitation. Currently, you can add multiple pop accounts to a space, but there is no way to view the mail to each account separately. So the heavy flow accounts completely swamp all the others. The alternative which we've been using is to create a space per account, but we are starting to see that this doesn't scale very well.

Some thoughts:
* if more than one account is archived to a space, then the account name should be shown as a sortable column
* if more than one account is shown, it would be good to have a summary page listing the accounts, where clicking on an account would show just its email
* similarly when searching it should be possible to see which account the email was going to
* I would also like to see the account name in the URL so that it is clearer what you are looking at

It would also help if the main mail page looked more like a page in the space:

e.g.

http://wiki.progress.com/display/sup/mail/

not:

http://wiki.progress.com/spaces/viewmailarchive.action?key=sup

Apologies if this has been added since 2.2.2. We are planning to finally upgrade in the next month or so.

  {panel}

The subconf plugin (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFEXT/Subconf) has to hook into the attachment subsystem.
Unfortunately when I first wrote it, I couldn't find a clean way to integrate it.
Basically there is a delegating attachment manager that delegates to either the file based, database based or web dav based attachment manager based on a global setting.
The component names for these three managers is hardcoded in a bit of logic in the delegating attachment manager.
Further, I wanted to only delegate to the subconf attachment manager if svn integration was set up for a particular space.
I initially thought about just hacking the confluence spring xml file to replace the delegating attachment manager. But you can't even do that, as the classes for the plugin havent been loaded at confluence start up, so you get a class not found error.

So the nasty solution I came up with is this - get the spring app context, and inject my attachment manager in place of the file based attachment manager. This only works because the delegating attachment manager looks up the file based attachment manager every call, rather than having it injected at startup time.
This involves quite a lot of down casting of the app context and (ahem) a couple of calls to private methods.

So my question is - is there a better way to do this without the hack? I guess I need either a plugin point in the attachment sub system, or a more generalised method of replacing confluence components.

Currently there is no way to view all changes made to a space since a given date. Such details are only available on a page-by-page basis.

I'd like to see a way that would let you view a list of all pages that have changed just by selecting a date, and drilling into them you'd see the version changes between current the version just prior to that date.

Additionally, it'd be nice to allow us to provide changes in a space export. Exporting a space means taking all content offline, either to hand off to someone in physical version or someone who does not have Confluence access. The problem is that for successive exports you don't know what changed without drilling into the space details (for me: going in Recently Updated, drilling into each page, finding the version prior to the date you exported it, and clicking to see the changes, then printing to PDF).

if this were up to me, I would include a checkbox on the Space export page asking me if I wanted to export Revisions as well. Unchecked by default. Next to it would be a date selector (disabled when Revision checkbox is not checked), which I could use to select a date. if checked, the export would then provide the version changes following each page's most current content -- similar to how the RSS feed displays changes (see attached). In color of course.
fields.summary: View space-wide changes since XXX date

It would be nice to have an Administrator link or identifier that tells space admin that they currently have permission in the space they are currently in as well as allow normal users to easily identify space admin or problems within a space. 

We rolled Confluence out by establishing space admins for each department. Although there is a wiki page, people new to the wiki have found it difficult knowing who to contact while in a space.

Also the space admin said they would prefer one click int he top right hand corner to access the administration rather then 3 to 4 click depends on what you want to change. Confluence instances are licensed for a set number of users.  Administrators frequently ask how to remove one or more users so they can add new users without having to increase the number allowed by their licence.  Currently we tell them to effectively deactivate those users by removing the "Use Confluence" permission from them, both directly and via their inclusion in groups. http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Removing+a+User

The problem that many many administrators then face is that the number of users actively using the system is somehow cached.  (I believe it's their membership of groups that is the problem but I haven't checked).

This means that in order to add new users, they must:

1) remove permissions from existing users
2) wait a while (or clear the caches from the cache statistics page).
3) add new users.
fields.summary: Active User cache is not cleared when users are removed from groups

Currently there is no way to totally remove an existing user if such user has already created some content.
The alternative of deactivating the user addressed this problem just partially, those users can still get listed publicly, they are still somehow around the system.
This turns into a security issue.
When working with groups/users/permissions the inactive users listed and available in the search.

When working with permissions, it would be helpful if inactive users were not listed or available when selecting individual users (i.e. need to make a user active before it can be selected for use).  The inactive users should not be shown in the search list of the user while adding a new user in the group.

Cheers!
Hernan

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8062].
  {panel}

The "trash" can for deleted pages only shows:

1. The Page Title
2. Restore/Delete Options.

Ideally, what we'd like is for the activity of deleted pages to be logged, and that information displayed on the page. 

What we are looking for in addition to the 2 points listed above are:

1. The Timestamp of when the page was deleted
2. The User who deleted the page
3. Create a log file that will log this type of activity.
fields.summary: Logging and Extra Information for Deleted Pages Description

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8061].
  {panel}

Presently, there is no "fall-back" available when deleted entire spaces - i.e. once you remove a space it is deleted permanently. 

It would be helpful to have the "trash" feature like with deleting individual pages, so that Spaces which are removed can be restored with ease.

Ivan has suggested the following procedure:

1. Once a space is deleted, change the flag in the database table for that Space to "deleted"
2. Keep the Space in the table, but inactive.
3. Only delete the space permanently if the user "Purges" the trash.
4. Change the flag from "deleted" back to normal status, should the space be restored.
5. Log the activity of deletion; i.e. Log the timestamp for when the space was deleted, and by whom. 
6. Create a log file to log all this activity.
fields.summary: Rollback/Recovery option for Deleted Spaces

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8017].
  {panel}

Here's the basic idea.  No matter how fast Confluence becomes working on the local machine is always going to be faster.  So having something like TiddlyWiki is very useful.  However, the problem immediately becomes how to synchronize work done in Tiddlywiki across multiple machines.

What would be really cool is to come up with a plugin/modified Tiddlywiki, whatever it takes to make it so that you could use Tiddlywiki locally and have it automatically save up to a configured Confluence wiki.  Or even better, make a TiddlyWiki clone that uses Confluence's markup language.

Think of it sort of like "Confluence-Lite" or something.  Heck, this could even be a nice way to deal with disconnected Confluence wiki content management.

Anyway, just an idea as I stumbled around looking for a nice server side solution for Tiddlywiki to sync it up on multiple machines.
fields.summary: Plugin, macro or feature to support integration with TiddlyWiki (or a Confluence equivalent of Tiddlywiki)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8013].
  {panel}

We have hundreds of users, which are members of hundreds of LDAP groups, and we have several dozen spaces that are managed by various space admins.

When LDAP changes groups around, or when space admins alter permissions, our users often lose their ability to access pages.

REQUEST: (optionally) send the site administrator a notification when a space administrator adds/removes/changes the space permissions AND/OR allow admin to see all permission changes by space in reverse chronological order.

see also: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-8012
fields.summary: Site admins are not notified when space admins add users, especially those who are not permitted on the site

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8012].
  {panel}

We have hundreds of users, which are members of hundreds of LDAP groups, and we have several dozen spaces that are managed by various space admins.

When LDAP changes groups around, or when space admins alter permissions, our users often lose their ability to access pages.

if there was an indication, at the space level on the permissions screen, for the space administrator, that the person or group that the admin has just added has one or more members that would NOT be able to access the space because they were not permitted via the SITE permissions, then the space admin could contact the site admin immediately and solve the problem without the users having to get a 'not permitted' error.

REQUEST: Put a red-flag indicator beside ant group or individual, on the space permission tab, which indicates one or more members are not also listed on the site permissions.
fields.summary: Site and Space permissions are difficult to keep syncrhonized in large or complex environments

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8011].
  {panel}

When you click on a label, it takes you to a nice interface that shows you all of the content where that label is used.  However, you have to infer by the content what the intention / use of the label is for.  Does 'conf' mean confluence or configuration or something else entirely? Is it a list of articles that are about confluence? refer to confluence? articles that should be moved to the confluence space, or need to be updated when confluence is change? Probably all of the above.

It would be excellent to have a 'wiki section at the top of the LABELS tab for a space, where the labelled content is shown, where you can describe the purpose of the label and perhaps provided guidance and contact info for the labels owner.

This is more relevant for some labels than others. chemistry, draft or featured-article labels might all have different meanings to different people and it's important to have a tool by which to explain these things.

One hack implementation we've done is to create a 'labels' space, with a page name there equivalent to each label we want to document. Then we hacked the page LABELS UI to simply dynamically generate an {include:labels:labelname} and also an {include:labels:spacekey labelname} to get the space specific labels. Then we put a link to [labels:spacekey labelname] and [labels:labelname] so people knew where to go to update the info.  All this was displayed on the page you get when you click on [//label/mylabel] or [//label/spacekey/mylabel].

(likewise, i've recommended doing similar embeding of wik content in the UI  for user macros and the notation guide, in other Jira requests).

Thanks
fields.summary: Provide a 'wiki' contents space to describe purpose / ownership of labels

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-8010].
  {panel}

Prior to 2.7.1, when linking to pages in other spaces, using [key:title] generates exactly that [key:title] text inline. This often does not flow well in natural reading of paragraphs, and when pages are moves from one space to another, sometimes massive numbers of alias that were not originally created need to be updated.

The most common alias for [key:title] is [Title|key:title], which I type 100 times a day.

If we were to leave the space in the text, most commonly it's the 'space name' not the key, that we need rendered.

Recommend:

- Make the default rendering of [key:title] just show "Title". in the default hover text, indicate that it will be linking to a separate space. 
- People can always override this by typing [key:title|key:title] in the rare cases they want to see the key.

- create a configuration item "Show space keys for inter-space links by default". Default to 'true' for backward compatibility.

*note* allegedly, this request was fixed in 2.7.1
fields.summary: Display the Space Name, or at least do not display the space key, by default for key:title links

However, newer users tend not to like CamelCasing, or are experiencing problems with CamelCase links related to source code postings on wiki pages.

Twiki provided:
<noautolink>
RedHat &
SuSE
</noautolink>

Having this option set on a space by space level would also be very helpful.  http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-6526

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7952].
  {panel}

Almost all macros would benefit, for example from a parameter called 'context' or 'root' which lets you indicate which page you want the macro to execute from.

{include:root=pagename} (default parameter)
{toc:root=pagename} (not a current parameters, but would be nice)
{metadata-report:root=pagename} (current parameter)

Currently, all macros would have to re-implement this feature, and many do, and often give a different name. If confluence provided a $rootcontext variable to the macros, which was loaded from a standard 'root' or 'context' parameter, it would enforce standardization.

Other candidates for standardized 'global' parameters can be found on a page in the confluence extensions section, written by either Guy Fraser or David Peterson, but I couldn't find it right now. I'll list a few here:

pages - takes a well-written query language that allows macros to simply recieve a list of pages on which to perform their action (such as a $pages collection), but without each macro having to re-invent or re-implement a (different) query language. It could take:
- list of specific pages, or space:pages, with a standard delimiter ( ; ? )
- wildcards or regular expressions to indicate a group of pages by name
- perhaps keywords or symbols like @children, @parent of the current page
- space key designations
- as the 'parser' changes or becomes more sophisticated, existing macros woudl all benefit from these changes because they simply use the $pages collection.

labels - same as above: sets $pages to a set of pages that satify a 'label query', with () for nesting and some operators for and/or/not ( + , ! )

scope - descendents, ancestors, space, site, children, parent, self - specifies dynamic scope relative to the 'pages' option, or might be incorporated in the pages query language

query - uses the built in query language, i.e "title:My Page* AND author:james") to retrieve a set of pages for the macro's operation

style - specify a direct CSS style for this tag. These could then, in theory, be filterd by a per site configuration for all macros
css - specify a css class. likewise, could then be manipulated / translate site-wide for all macros

output - wiki / table / html / text (specified how output sould be rendered in page context after macro returns results)
input - wiki / table / html / text (specified how input should be rendered before passed to $body for macro plugin)

There are no doubt others that could be used. This request is for Atlassian to put in place the framework to support these 'global macro parameters'.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Create a set of useful global macro parameters which macro developers can use without re-inventing

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7950].
  {panel}

It would be nice to be able to send somebody a link taking them to the "view difference" pages for two specific versions of a file (like the output of diffpagesbyversion.action).

Example scenario: 

A page is being used to track project status. There is a weekly review meeting to discuss the project.
The ability to send link showing diffs between the page after the last review meeting compared with the current status would be useful. 
Note that last meeting may not be the previous version in Confluence since other changes may have been made between meetings.

Doesn't need to be pretty - something like http://wiki.wiki.com/pages/diffpagesbyversion.action?pageId=9992&v1=1234&v2=5678 would do.

Would be nice to have a specific code for the "current" version. For example - http://wiki.wiki.com/pages/diffpagesbyversion.action?pageId=9992&v1=1234&v2=current
fields.summary: Add ability to link to differences between specific page versions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7948].
  {panel}

Allow an anchor to be specified when linking to a Confluence attachment.

For instance if I have a PDF called MyDocument.pdf and I want to link directly to page 4 I should be able to link to it thusly:

[Page 4 of My Document|MySpace^MyDocument.pdf#page=4]

PDF readers process URL anchors to jump straight to the desired page.
fields.summary: Allow the specification of an anchor when linking to attachments

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7945].
  {panel}

Users appear to be manually adding anonymous comment spam to public Confluence instances such as http://confluence.atlassian.com

If captcha is bypassed, it would be useful to allow logged-in users the option of flagging comments or pages as spam. 

At the bottom of each page should be a 'Report Spam' option for logged-in users only. Clicking this link adds the label 'spam' to the page. If the page already has the label 'spam', the link should read 'Remove Spam Flag'

Administrators can then monitor an RSS feed or watch for pages marked as spam.
fields.summary: Add 'Report Spam' Option For Logged In Users

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-7940].
  {panel}

The Confluence "Standard Installation" uses the Embedded HSQL database.  When doing a Custom Installation the user is told that HSQL should not be used in production instances.  

The implication is that a "Standard Installation" is in fact a "non-production Installation".  

Wouldn't "Demonstration Installation" or "Test Installation" or "Dodgy, Non Production, Easy Express Installation" be better terms?

That way people wouldn't keep asking: "Why did nobody tell us that HSQL wasn't for production instances?"
fields.summary: Standard Installation not really standard
